title: R45268
content: This report analyzes annual appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2019, comparing enacted FY2018 appropriations, the Trump Administration's FY2019 budget request, and Congress's response. It provides additional informational resources on DHS appropriations and a list of CRS policy experts for consultation. The suite of CRS reports on homeland security appropriations focuses on legislative action and congressional issues related to discretionary funding amounts, not mandatory funding or other legislation. The report analyzes annual appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2019, comparing enacted FY2018 appropriations, the Trump Administration's FY2019 budget request, and Congress's response. It focuses on legislative action and congressional issues related to discretionary funding amounts, not mandatory funding or other legislation. The discussion of appropriations legislation involves specialized budgetary concepts, with the Appendix explaining terms such as budget authority, obligations, outlays, discretionary and mandatory spending, and adjustments to discretionary spending caps under the Budget Control Act. All amounts in CRS reports on homeland security appropriations represent budget authority. Data used in this report for FY2018 amounts are derived from the explanatory statement accompanying P.L. 115-141, the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017—Division F of which is the Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2018. The explanatory statement also includes data on FY2018 supplemental appropriations for DHS enacted prior to the development of the consolidated appropriations act for FY2018. Data for the FY2019 requested levels and enacted levels are drawn from H.Rept. 116-9, the explanatory statement accompanying P.L. 116-6. Data on the Senate Appropriations Committee recommendation are drawn from. The process of enacting appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security for FY2019 involved the Administration's initial request, committee actions in the House and Senate, continuing appropriations, and the enactment of the consolidated appropriations bill. Data from the Senate and House Appropriations Committees, along with the Congressional Budget Office methodology, were used for scoring. The report does not compare this data with the Office of Management and Budget data due to technical scoring differences. The Trump Administration released its budget request for FY2019, including additional requests for resources for DHS. They requested $47.43 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority for DHS, a decrease of 0.6% from the previous year. The Trump Administration requested $47.43 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority for DHS for FY2019, a decrease of 0.6% from the previous year. Additionally, they requested an extra $6.65 billion for FEMA in disaster relief funding and $165 million in OCO funding for the Coast Guard. The Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2019, included $48.33 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority for FY2019, which was above the Administration's request and the enacted level for FY2018. The bill also included disaster relief funding and OCO-designated funding for the Coast Guard. The House Appropriations Committee marked up their version of the bill, H.R. 6776, which included $51.44 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget. The House committee-reported bill for FY2019 did not include OCO funding for the Coast Guard and did not see action on the House floor. A consolidated appropriations bill with a continuing resolution was passed on September 28, 2018, as P.L. 115-245, which led to a partial shutdown of DHS for 35 days when annual appropriations lapsed. On February 14, 2019, the House passed a consolidated appropriations bill that included the Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2019, with $49.41 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority. This was $1.69 billion more than FY2018 and $2.04 billion more than requested by the Administration. The bill also included $12 billion for major disasters, $5.35 billion more than requested, and $165 million in OCO funding for the Coast Guard. It passed the House by 300-128 and the Senate by 83-16. The homeland security appropriations bill, passed by the House and Senate, was signed into law by the President the next day. It allocates resources to every departmental component of DHS, with discretionary appropriations providing the majority of funding. The budget also includes fee revenues, trust funds, and mandatory spending. Appropriations measures for DHS are typically organized into five titles, with the first four grouping components thematically and the fifth providing general direction to the department. When DHS was established in 2003, components of other agencies were brought together over a matter of months, in the midst of ongoing budget cycles. Congress and the Administration continued to provide resources through existing account structures when possible. In 2014, DHS began working on a new Common Appropriations Structure (CAS) at the direction of Congress. In 2014, DHS started developing a new Common Appropriations Structure (CAS) to standardize appropriations format. Operating with numerous appropriations and programs hindered transparency and decision-making. By FY2019, most DHS components aligned their funding requests with the CAS. In FY2019, DHS components aligned funding requests with the Common Appropriations Structure (CAS). The fifth title of the FY2019 DHS appropriations act includes rescissions of prior-year appropriations. For FY2019, the Administration proposed rescinding $300 million in prior-year funding from the DRF. In FY2019, the DHS appropriations act included rescissions of prior-year appropriations, with $303 million in rescissions and $300 million from the DRF redirected to other activities within DHS. Funding for the Financial Systems Modernization initiative and Presidential Residence Protection costs were also included in the budget. Amendments in H.R. 6776 resulted in a $13 million increase in costs. For more information on FY2019 DHS appropriations, refer to CRS reports R44604, R44052, and R45262. The federal government spending process involves budget authority enacted by Congress, funds obligated by federal agencies, and payments made to liquidate those obligations. Budget authority is determined through appropriations acts or direct spending legislation. The Antideficiency Act prohibits agencies from obligating more funds than enacted budget authority. The Antideficiency Act prohibits federal agencies from obligating more funds than the budget authority enacted by Congress. Budget authority can be indefinite, one-year, multiyear, or no-year. Obligations are incurred when agencies engage in transactions, creating a legal requirement for the government to pay, while outlays are the funds actually spent. Budget authority allows federal agencies to incur obligations and authorizes payments to be made from the Treasury. It consists of discretionary and mandatory spending, with discretionary spending appropriated yearly by Congress. Gross budget authority is the total funds available for spending by a federal agency. The Budget Enforcement Act of 1990 defines discretionary appropriations as budget authority provided in annual appropriations acts, excluding entitlements. Mandatory spending, also known as direct spending, consists of budget authority provided in laws other than appropriations acts. Some mandatory entitlement programs must be appropriated each year. Within DHS, Coast Guard retirement pay is an example of appropriated mandatory spending. Offsetting collections are funds collected by the federal government as part of a business-type transaction, not considered federal revenue but counted as negative outlays. The DHS net discretionary budget authority is composed of discretionary spending minus any fee or fund collections that offset discretionary spending. Some collections offset an agency's discretionary budget authority, while others offset an agency's mandatory spending, which includes entitlement programs like the Secret Service and Coast Guard retired pay accounts. Secret Service retirement pay is funded by permanent appropriations. The DHS budget includes Secret Service retirement pay funded by permanent appropriations, while Coast Guard retirement pay is annually appropriated. Additionally, the budget contains Trust and Public Enterprise Funds that are not appropriated by Congress. The maximum budget authority for annual appropriations is determined through a two-stage congressional budget process, with allocations known as 302(a) allocations. The 302(a) allocations are discretionary totals available to House and Senate Committees on Appropriations for annual appropriations bills. The appropriations committees then allocate the 302(a) funds among subcommittees for each bill as 302(b) allocations, which must not exceed the 302(a) allocation to enforce budget discipline. Adjustments can be made during the year by the appropriations committee as bills progress towards enactment. The appropriations bills progress towards final enactment with no subcommittee allocations developed for conference reports or enacted appropriations bills. Table A-1 shows comparable figures for the 302(b) allocation for FY2018, FY2019 President's request, and House and Senate subcommittee allocations for the Homeland Security appropriations bills. The Budget Control Act established enforceable discretionary limits for defense and nondefense spending, with adjustments allowed to cover funding for overseas. The Budget Control Act allows for adjustments to raise statutory caps for overseas contingency operations, emergency spending, disaster relief, and other appropriations. Three justifications for adjusting discretionary budget authority caps have influenced DHS's appropriations process. Adjustments for emergency spending and overseas contingency operations are unlimited, while disaster relief is limited. The allowable adjustment for disaster relief was determined by OMB using a specific formula until FY2019. The Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018 increased the allowable adjustment for disaster relief by adding 5% of emergency-designated funding for major disasters under the Stafford Act. OMB estimated the allowable adjustment for FY2019 at $14.965 billion, with $12 billion used in appropriations for the Disaster Relief Fund. No other annual appropriations utilized the disaster relief adjustment for FY2019.
